instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01521: What is 820-01521? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP1V8_SLPS2R: What is PP1V8_SLPS2R? PP1V8_SLPS2R is a 1.8v power rail present when the system is in a SLPS2R state. .
definitions.PP1V1_SLPS2R: What is PP1V1_SLPS2R? The PP1V1_SLPS2R power rail in the MacBook schematic provides a 1.1-volt supply in a specific low-power state indicated by the "_SLPS2R" suffix and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.PP1V8_AWAKE: What is PP1V8_AWAKE? The PP1V8_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is indicative of a power rail that delivers 1.8 volts when the machine is in an "awake" state. This is not a traditional power state defined in the older Intel PCH documentation; it seems to be specific to newer MacBook architectures. The "awake" designation likely refers to a state where the MacBook is on and ready for user interaction, but it is not necessarily at full operational capacity (which would be denoted by an S0 state).
definitions.A1932: What is A1932? A1932 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Late 2018, 2019 with EMC 3184, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01521..
definitions.PP0V9_SSD: What is PP0V9_SSD? PP0V9_SSD is a power rail that powers the soldered on NAND memory for the SSD on Macbooks with soldered on storage and must be present for the SSD to show up. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 - 5V 0.43A - No liquid damage - <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> warms up
threads.message:
Tried DFU mode but did not get picked up.

Under IR <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> seems to warm up to 34*C
[ATTACH alt="2022-02-01 21-16-38.JPG"]60397[/ATTACH][ATTACH alt="2022-02-01 21-17-36.JPG"]60396[/ATTACH]

No visible shorts on coils, low impedance on
P0V9SLPDDR_SW0 - 53Ohm
P0V9SLPDDR_SW1 - 53Ohm

While
P1V1SLPS2R_SW0 - 8.9kOhm
P1V1SLPS2R_SW1 - 11kOhm

Lifted up L7186/Lt187 low impedance seems to be on the <SIGNAL>PP0V9_SLPDDR</SIGNAL> side. Is that normal?

Where else shall I look?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 - 5V 0.43A - No liquid damage - <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> warms up
threads.message: Do you get correct voltage at L8100?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 - 5V 0.43A - No liquid damage - <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> warms up
threads.message:
P0V9SLPDDR_SW0 - 1.56V
P0V9SLPDDR_SW1 - 1.55V
PWDDCPUAWAKE_SW1/3 - 0.75V
others fine


Only these I am not getting on <CHIP>U8100</CHIP> coils
CPUCore - 0V
P1VPRIM - 0V
<SIGNAL>P0V9SSD_SW0</SIGNAL> - 0V
<SIGNAL>P1V8SSD_SW0</SIGNAL> - 0V

All on the right side of <CHIP>U8100</CHIP>
[ATTACH alt="IT-<SIGNAL>SOLVE_REPAIR_22</SIGNAL>-02-<SIGNAL>02_07</SIGNAL>-59-40.jpg"]60399[/ATTACH]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 - 5V 0.43A - No liquid damage - <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> warms up
threads.message:
Apologies. Yes, it is <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>, working on 2 macs at the same time does your brain.

Corrected

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 - 5V 0.43A - No liquid damage - <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> warms up
threads.message:
Don't check for DC voltage at "SW" side of a coil.
Always test the output pin (DC side), where the filter cap is placed.
If you use an o-scope, will probably understand the difference.

Check if all AWAKE and SLPS2R voltages are present.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 - 5V 0.43A - No liquid damage - <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> warms up
threads.message:
So we should measure after the coil on outputs, rather than on the output pin side instead?

[ATTACH type="full" alt="1643763006701.png"]60402[/ATTACH]


<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> - 1.8V
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> - 1.1V
<SIGNAL>PP0V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> - 0V
Let me know if I missed any


<SIGNAL>P0V9SSD_SW0</SIGNAL>  and <SIGNAL>PP0V9_SLPDDR</SIGNAL> seem to get 1.6V now. After I unsoldered and soldered back L7816/7 not sure if related. Isn't 1.6V a bit too high for a 0.9V line?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 - 5V 0.43A - No liquid damage - <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> warms up
threads.message:
I said do NOT check DC voltage on "SW" side of coil.
What is L7823 pin 1 voltage and pin2 of L7816/17?
These are the output pins for mentioned coils.

"<SIGNAL>PP0V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> - 0V"
This is a "good" reason for non working board.
Check diode mode to ground there.

Also check AWAKE voltages from the same page.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 - 5V 0.43A - No liquid damage - <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> warms up
threads.message:
Roger that. Strange that all test points are placed there. Must be for o-scope.

L7823  -  0V - 0.373
L7816/17 - 1.57V

<SIGNAL>PP0V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> - 0.79V - 0.2389 -  I must have mismeasured it.

<SIGNAL>PPVDDCPU_AWAKE</SIGNAL> - 0.75V
PPVDDCPUSRAM_AWAKE - 0.80V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_AWAKE</SIGNAL> - 1.8V


All the remaining reported voltages are the same.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 - 5V 0.43A - No liquid damage - <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> warms up
threads.message:
Just got functioning <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> and referenced core diode mode readings on these 0V lines

<SIGNAL>PVCC_PRIM_CORE</SIGNAL> - 0.074 - 0.308 on a functioning board
<SIGNAL>PP1V_PRIM</SIGNAL> - 0.092 - 0.26
<SIGNAL>PP0V9_SSD</SIGNAL> - 0.064 - 0.276

Blown CPU / SSD? Not much dusty, used for high school classes mainly.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 - 5V 0.43A - No liquid damage - <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> warms up
threads.message:
You can try changing <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>.

Once you've got working board on hands, write down diode mode readings on all coils, including the big ones.
This way build a boards library, which will save you time in the future.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 - 5V 0.43A - No liquid damage - <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> warms up
threads.message:

threads.message:
Just for confirmation, I have lifted up all coils on these lines and seems like short is [U]no[/U]t on the side of the PMIC

[ATTACH type="full" width="631px"]60405[/ATTACH]

<SIGNAL>PPVCC_PRIM_CORE</SIGNAL> - 0.0169
<SIGNAL>PP1V_PRIM</SIGNAL> - 0.0254
<SIGNAL>PP0V9_SSD</SIGNAL> - 0.35

Could that PMIC is fine unless <SIGNAL>PVCC_PRIM_CORE</SIGNAL>, inputs of it are blown (AE/F 18/19)?
